usages.pl: Can something be very {parahw}unique{/parahw} or somewhat unique?
pt: Many commentators have objected to the comparison or modification (as by {it}somewhat{/it} or {it}very{/it}) of {it}unique{/it}, often asserting that a thing is either unique or it is not. Objections are based chiefly on the assumption that {it}unique{/it} has but a single absolute sense, an assumption contradicted by information readily available in a dictionary. {it}Unique{/it} dates back to the 17th century but was little used until the end of the 18th when, according to the Oxford English Dictionary, it was reacquired from French. H. J. Todd entered it as a foreign word in his edition (1818) of Johnson's Dictionary, characterizing it as "affected and useless." Around the middle of the 19th century it ceased to be considered foreign and came into considerable popular use. With popular use came a broadening of application beyond the original two meanings (here numbered senses 1 and 2a). In modern use both comparison and modification are widespread and standard but are confined to the extended senses 2b and 3. When sense 1 or sense 2a is intended, {it}unique{/it} is used without qualifying modifiers.

{sc}strange{/sc} {sc}singular{/sc} {sc}unique{/sc} {sc}peculiar{/sc} {sc}eccentric{/sc} {sc}erratic{/sc} {sc}odd{/sc} {sc}quaint{/sc} {sc}outlandish{/sc} mean departing from what is ordinary, usual, or to be expected. {sc}strange{/sc} stresses unfamiliarity and may apply to the foreign, the unnatural, the unaccountable.
{sc}unique{/sc} implies singularity and the fact of being without a known parallel.

pt.t: a career {it}unique{/it} in the annals of science
the {it}peculiar{/it} status of America's First Lady

pt: {sc}eccentric{/sc} suggests a wide divergence from the usual or normal especially in behavior.
{sc}erratic{/sc} stresses a capricious and unpredictable wandering or deviating.
{sc}odd{/sc} applies to a departure from the regular or expected.
{sc}quaint{/sc} suggests an old-fashioned but pleasant oddness.
{sc}outlandish{/sc} applies to what is uncouth, bizarre, or barbaric.

quotes.t: There are no clear blueprints to be discovered in history that can help us shape the future as we wish. Each historical event is a {qword}unique{/qword} congeries of factors, people, or chronology.
[Tiger] Wood's {qword}unique{/qword} skill set was on display again at last week's U.S. Open, but this victory was more visceral. It was all heart.
Space is a strange and {qword}unique{/qword} item—you can't take it to a lab and analyze it like beef jerky.

A century ago a doctor was considered to be part of a social elite. He—and medicine was then very much a masculine endeavor—had a {qword}unique{/qword} mastery of a special body of knowledge. He professed a commitment to levels of competence and integrity that he expected society to respect and trust.

Most stars are not born in isolation but instead in groups of several thousand to tens of thousands, all of which emerge from the same parent cloud of gas. Each cloud has a {qword}unique{/qword} and homogeneous mix of chemical elements and isotopes, which its stellar progeny inherits. Even when the stars disperse, they retain their {qword}unique{/qword} chemical tag …
As a dozen new books will testify, our nation is in the midst of a great barbecue renaissance, with each region proudly claiming its own {qword}unique{/qword} style.

shortdef: being without a like or equal : unequaled
